content.text: How Toxicity Works

Toxicity measures ambient magic saturation in your body. Magic is everywhere in 3025 — it powers infrastructure, it leaks from rifts, it’s in the air. Channeling it directly or being exposed to concentrated sources builds it up. Your body can handle some. Too much and you become a resource to be harvested.
Toxicity Track: 0 to max (default max: 20, modified by Grit and augments/mutations).
Toxicity is not a combat mechanic in most cases. It’s a mission-level and downtime-level pressure that creates long-term decision-making.
Sources of Toxicity Gain
Source Toxicity Gained Frequency
Entering a rift +1 Per mission in a rift zone
Extended rift +1d4 Per mission exposure (2+ hours in a rift)
Using magic-category +1 per use (varies by Per combat weapons weapon)
Channeling raw Varies by ability Per use magic (Rift tree abilities)
Rift anomaly +1d6 Per incident exposure (touching weird stuff)
Catastrophic rift +2d6 Per event event (breach, collapse, surge)
Certain mutations +1/day or per mission Passive (Rift-Beast Heart, etc.)
Certain mutation +2 in rift zones Per mission complications (Toxicity Magnet, etc.)
Corp toxicity Variable Punitive / coerced injection (yes, this is a thing) ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Natural Dispersal
Toxicity disperses slowly on its own when you’re not being exposed.
Activity Toxicity Cleared
Normal downtime (city living) -1 per downtime period
Rest downtime (doing nothing -2 per downtime period productive)
Rural/clean environment -3 per downtime period
Toxicity Scrubber (consumable, -2 (immediate) 150 cr)
Clinical Detox (medical -1d6 (takes full downtime period, facility) 200 cr)
Black Market Purge (dangerous) -2d6 (takes full downtime, 100 cr, roll 1d20 vs DC 7 — fail = gain a Minor complication)
Rift Mastery augment Double natural dispersal rate outside rifts

Key tension: Taking a “rest downtime“ to clear toxicity means you’re not learning skills, not treating scars, not working for credits, and not installing augments. Every downtime period is a single-choice resource. Toxicity recovery competes with everything else.
Toxicity Thresholds
As toxicity climbs, effects escalate. These thresholds apply at the listed levels relative to your max. Default max is 20.
Toxicity Threshold Effect

25% (5/20) Trace Levels — Your skin has a faint Glowing luminescence in darkness. Barely visible, but rift creatures can sense you more easily. -1 to Stealth checks in rift zones. Corp scanners at gates register “elevated“ — no action taken, but logged.

40% (8/20) Moderate — Ambient magic visibly Leaking arcs off your body when stressed. Electronics near you occasionally glitch. -1 to all Interface checks involving delicate equipment. Corp scanners flag you for “recommended detox“ — optional but noted in your file.

50% (10/20) High — Unstable Your body is a magic capacitor. Once per session, the GM can trigger an involuntary magic discharge — 1d4 damage to everything within melee range (including allies). You can’t control it. Happens during stress, combat, or strong emotions. Corp scanners flag “mandatory detox“ — refusal noted.

70% (14/20) Severe — Persistent effects: Saturated your touch temporarily disrupts electronics, rift creatures are attracted to you from further away, and you gain +1 toxicity from ALL sources (accelerating spiral). -1 to all stat checks. Corp scanners flag “asset risk“ — security may detain you for “evaluation.“

85% (17/20) Critical — Your body is a rift Overloading battery. Constant visible magic aura. -2 to all stat checks. All allies within short range gain +1 toxicity per mission just from proximity to you. You are now a hazard to your team. Corp scanners flag “extraction priority“ — they will try to take you.

100% (20/20) Terminal — Harvest You have reached Threshold corporate harvest threshold. Your body contains enough ambient magic to be worth more as raw material than as a contractor. Corps issue an extraction order. Rift creatures actively seek you. If you are not detoxed within one mission, you are seized, sedated, and processed. Character is effectively lost — they become a battery in a corporate power facility. This is not death. It is worse. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Threshold Math With Modifiers
The default max is 20. Augments and mutations can modify this:
Modifier Effect
Grit 6+                             +2 max toxicity
Grit 8+                             +4 max toxicity (replaces, doesn’t stack with above)
Grit 10+                            +6 max toxicity
Toxicity Filter (Rift T2 augment)   +2 max toxicity
Rift-Walker Suit (armor)            +1 max toxicity

A Channeler with Grit 8, Toxicity Filter, and Rift-Walker Suit has a max toxicity of 20 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 27. Their thresholds shift accordingly (25% of 27 = \~7, 100% = 27). They can absorb more magic before the walls close in. But the walls still close in.
Toxicity as Narrative Pressure
Toxicity isn’t meant to kill contractors directly (that’s what scars are for). It’s meant to create escalating social and logistical pressure:
At low toxicity (0-25%): No problems. You’re clean. Take contracts, go through gates, live your life.
At moderate toxicity (25-50%): Minor inconveniences. You glow a little. Scanners log you. It’s manageable but it’s in your file. Corps don’t act yet, but they’re watching.

At high toxicity (50-70%): Real problems. Involuntary discharges that hurt allies. Equipment malfunctions. Corps are “recommending“ detox. The team starts noticing. Your character’s presence has a cost.

At severe toxicity (70-85%): You are a liability. Your teammates gain toxicity from being near you. Corps are actively trying to detain you. The team has to decide: do we keep this person, knowing they’re making all of us hotter?

At terminal toxicity (100%): The game changes. You’re not a contractor anymore. You’re a resource. Corps issue extraction orders. Rift creatures hunt you. Your teammates either help you detox immediately or lose you.

The beauty is that toxicity creates team-level decisions, not just individual ones. A high-toxicity Channeler is still the best damage dealer on the team — but their presence is literally poisoning everyone around them. Do you bench them? Spend a fortune on detox? Accept the risk? That’s the drama.
Toxicity + Scars Interaction
At Toxicity 50%+ (High), scar treatment becomes more complicated:

• Licensed Surgeon scar treatment DC increases by +2 (your body is harder to work on when saturated with magic)  • Street Doc scar treatment DC increases by +4  • Self-treatment becomes nearly impossible (DC 12 + 4 = DC 16, with disadvantage)
At Toxicity 70%+ (Severe), augment installation is affected:
• All augment installation checks take -2 (magic interference with chrome integration)  • Mutation complication rolls take -2 (your biology is already destabilized)

This creates a cascading pressure: high toxicity makes it harder to treat scars, scars make you more fragile, fragility means more risky missions, risky missions mean more toxicity. The spiral tightens.
Corp Toxicity Scanning
Corps scan for toxicity at gates, checkpoints, and facility entrances. This is how they identify harvest candidates.
Scan Result Corp Response
Clean (0-25%) Waved through. No flag.
Elevated (25-40%) Logged. No action. Your file gets a note.
Recommended Detox (40-50%) Logged. Optional detox offered (corp clinic, 200 cr — subsidized to keep you working). Refusal noted but no consequences yet.
Mandatory Detox (50-70%) Flagged. You are “strongly encouraged“ to detox. Refusal may result in contract penalties, reduced pay, or assignment to low-exposure missions (which pay less).
Asset Risk (70-85%) Security may detain you for “evaluation.“ This is a polite word for “they’re deciding if you’re more valuable working or harvested.“ Contractors at this level often go off-grid.

Extraction Priority (85-100%) Active extraction order. Corporate security teams will attempt to take you. You are worth more as a battery than as an employee. This isn’t personal. It’s quarterly earnings. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------

Going off-grid: Contractors can avoid scanners by staying out of corporate areas. This means no corp contracts, no corp clinics, no corp stores. Black market only. Street docs only. The pay is worse and the work is more dangerous. But nobody is scanning you.
Voluntary Toxicity Use
Some contractors intentionally push their toxicity for power:

The Rift tree provides augments that convert toxicity into combat capability. Toxicity Weaponization (T3) adds damage based on current toxicity. Living Battery (T4) gives massive bonuses at +1 toxicity per round. These augments make toxicity a resource instead of just a liability — but the thresholds still apply.

Some missions pay toxicity bonuses. Deep rift work, long-exposure harvesting, and experimental contracts offer premium pay specifically because they’ll raise your toxicity. The corp is buying your future health for present productivity. Sound familiar?

Toxicity stacking for the endgame: A Channeler at 60% toxicity with the Rift tree is a walking weapon. They’re also one bad mission from the 70% threshold where their teammates start getting irradiated. The power curve and the danger curve are the same line. That’s the design.

How Mutations Differ From Augments
Augments Mutations
Source Chrome. Hardware. Biology. Gene-splicing. Circuits. Creature grafts.
Acquisition Buy → Install. Buy → Splice → Roll for Predictable. complications.
Cost structure Credits only Credits + complication risk
Reversibility Uninstall possible Permanent. You are this now.
Balance Pure bonuses (some EVERY mutation has a trade-offs by choice) bonus AND a cost
Progression Tier-locked by augment Risk-tier locked by how count much you’re willing to gamble
Feel Corporate. Clean. Biological horror. Transactional. Unpredictable. Personal. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Augments make you a better machine. Mutations make you a different creature. Both cost money. Only one costs you a piece of what you used to be.
Core Mechanic: The Complication Roll
Every mutation requires a Complication Roll when it’s installed. This determines if the splice takes cleanly or if something goes wrong.
The Roll
Roll 1d20 vs Complication DC
Risk Tier Complication DC Clean Splice Chance
Standard                DC 3                    90%
Low Risk                DC 7                    70%
High Risk               DC 12                   45%
Meet or exceed the DC = clean splice. The mutation installs with its intended bonus and its built-in cost. No additional problems.
Fail the DC = complication. The mutation still installs — you still get the bonus and the built-in cost — but you ALSO roll on the Complication Table for an additional side effect.
Provider Modifier: Gene-Doc vs Back-Alley
Where you get the work done matters.
Provider Effect Typical Price Modifier

Licensed Gene-Doc Normal roll (1d20) Base cost. Professional but no guarantees.
Street Splicer Normal roll (1d20), but 0.5x base cost. Cash DC increases by +2 only. No questions.
Back-Alley Hack Roll with 0.25x base cost. Might
disadvantage (roll be a vet. Might be a 2d20, take lower) butcher.

disadvantage, DC you, a mirror, and a increases by +3 syringe.

The money trap: A corp clinic makes Extreme Risk almost safe (DC 16 with advantage ≈ 64% clean), but costs 3x. A back-alley hack on a Standard mutation (DC 3 with disadvantage) can still go wrong. And that back-alley hack on an Extreme Risk mutation? DC 16 with disadvantage. Good luck.
Grit Modifier
Your body’s resilience matters. Add your Grit bonus to the Complication Roll.

A contractor with Grit 8 (+4 bonus) splicing High Risk at a gene-doc rolls 1d20+4 vs DC 12. That’s 65% clean instead of 45%. Grit matters here — it’s your body’s ability to absorb what’s being done to it.
Complication Tables
When you fail the Complication Roll, roll on the appropriate table based on how badly you failed.
Failure Severity

Severe Complications (d6)
Roll Complication
1 Organ Stress — One organ is failing slowly. -3 max HP. Replacement surgery available (800 cr, Low Risk complication roll).
2 Neural Rewiring — One stat permanently drops by 1 (GM rolls randomly). Your brain compensated for the mutation by sacrificing something else.
3 Augment Conflict — The mutation is biologically incompatible with one installed augment. Must choose: remove the augment or accept -2 to all checks while both are active.
4 Uncontrolled Expression — The mutation activates involuntarily in stress. Once per combat, GM triggers the bonus at a bad time (healing when you need damage, aggression during negotiation, etc.)
5 Accelerated Aging — Cellular degradation. You age visibly. Scar DCs increase by +1 across the board (stacks with scar count).
6 Toxicity Spike — Immediate +3 toxicity on installation. If this pushes you past threshold, that’s your problem. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
Critical Complications (d4)
Roll Complication
1 Total Rejection — Your body rejects the mutation violently. Gain 1 Scar immediately. Mutation bonus works but at half effect. Built-in cost doubled.

2 Cascading Failure — The splice destabilizes another mutation you have (random). That mutation gains a Moderate complication on top of its existing cost. If you have no other mutations, this hits your highest augment instead.

3 Rift Echo — The biological material remembers where it came from. You occasionally hear/see things from another dimension. -2 Interface permanently. Once per session, GM gives you unwanted (but sometimes useful) information from “the other side.“

4 Harvest Flag — The procedure attracted corporate attention. You are flagged in the system. A corp extraction team is now aware of you. This doesn’t go away. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------

Involuntary Mutations (Rift Exposure)

Sometimes the rift decides for you. When a contractor is exposed to high-concentration rift energy, the GM can assign a mutation directly — no purchase, no choice, no complication roll. The mutation just… happens.
Involuntary mutations always come with a complication. The GM chooses or rolls:

• Minor rift exposure → Standard/Low Risk mutation + Minor complication  • Major rift exposure → Any risk tier mutation + Moderate complication  • Catastrophic rift exposure → High/Extreme mutation + Severe complication
These are free in credits but never free in body. They’re the universe’s way of reminding you that the rift doesn’t care about your plans.

Involuntary mutations cannot be removed. They’re woven into your DNA now. A gene-doc might be able to suppress the complication (not the built-in cost) for 500 cr + a Standard complication roll. But the mutation itself? That’s you now.

Interaction With Other Systems
Mutations + Augments

• Both can be active simultaneously  • Some augments may conflict with specific mutations (GM discretion — if a mutation replaces an arm, chrome augments on that arm need re-evaluation)  • Augments are hardware. Mutations are software-on-wetware. They use different “slots“
Mutations + Scars
• Scar treatment doesn’t affect mutations • Mutation complications don’t count as Scars • BUT: the Accelerated Aging severe complication does affect Scar DCs
Mutations + Toxicity

• Several mutations interact with toxicity (Rift-Beast Heart, Toxicity Magnet complication)  • Mutations with rift-creature components may cause passive toxicity gain  • Toxicity threshold is still set by Grit + Rift tree augments — mutations don’t change it unless specifically stated
Mutations + Money

• Installation costs  • Provider tier costs (0.25x to 3x)  • Monthly maintenance for some complications  • Removal costs  • This is another drain in the economic loop. Another reason to take the next contract.
Design Notes for GMs

The risk-reward curve is the point. Standard mutations are almost free lunch — small bonus, small cost, high success rate. Extreme mutations are a different game — massive bonuses, real permanent costs, and a 75% complication rate at a back-alley hack (DC 16, disadvantage). Let players see the full curve before they decide.

Back-alley vs corp clinic is a money decision with consequences. The corp clinic is safe but expensive and they own your data. The back-alley hack is cheap but dangerous. This is the setting’s entire thesis in one mechanic: the safe option costs money you don’t have, and the dangerous option might cost you more.

Involuntary mutations are story tools. Don’t spam them. Use them when a rift encounter goes sideways, when a player touches something they shouldn’t, or when the narrative calls for a permanent change. One involuntary mutation per major story arc is plenty.

Complications are permanent (usually). Don’t let players hand-wave them. The Phantom Pain, the Dependency, the Neural Feedback — these are the scars of choosing to be something other than human. They should matter at the table. That said, some complications can be treated (at cost, with risk). The grind continues.

Homebrew mutations should follow the pattern: 1. Pick a risk tier based on how powerful the bonus is 2. Design a built-in cost from a different system than the bonus (combat bonus → social/utility cost, survival bonus → economic cost, etc.) 3. The cost should be meaningful but not crippling — it’s the price of entry, not the punishment 4. Complications from failed rolls are the punishment
The provider system is the GM’s best friend for economic pressure.

When a player can’t afford the gene-doc, they’ll go to the street splicer. When they can’t afford the street splicer, they’ll find the back-alley hack. When they’re truly desperate, they’ll try the self-splice kit. Each step down the ladder is a choice that says something about where this character is in their life. That’s drama. That’s Arcane Steel.
